Despite the growing awareness of the significance of ergonomics in the workplace, many consumers continue to believe that a cheap, poorly designed office chair would suffice as long as their desk is at the right height and their hands are in the correct position typing. They used to be under those false impressions, but after reading the six-page study, they no longer are.


You might wonder, "How do chairs affect my health at work?" The back, that's where it's at. Your back muscles will experience less strain if the chair you're sitting in provides adequate support for your lumbar region and pelvis.

The lack of back support in many chairs, coupled with prolonged sitting on the job, is a significant contributor to the fact that sedentary workers experience similar rates of lower back discomfort as their more mobile counterparts. Science has shown that prolonged sitting increases the probability of back problems, including ruptured discs.


Slouching and other related seated positions have been linked to a variety of health issues, including but not limited to back pain, headaches, exhaustion, and difficulty focusing. Whenever the spine is in its natural position, a person is more comfortable and can focus for lengthy periods when performing a seated task.


Back and pelvic support is essential for this ergonomic stance; back support alone is insufficient. As they were based on the habits of office employees before the computer became so ubiquitous, many seats marketed as office chairs provide inadequate support for the thighs and pelvis. Many now spend most of their working hours staring at and communicating with computers, which was not the case only 20 or so years ago.


Scrutinize your office chair to see if it provides adequate lumbar and pelvic support, improving posture, easier breathing, and reduced fatigue.

Many chairs labeled ergonomic don't meet all the criteria. If you want the optimum ergonomic support from your office chair, consider the following considerations.


Adjustability

Adjustability creates an excellent ergonomic office chair. Because everyone is different, each chair must be adaptable.


height

An excellent ergonomic chair has a seat height range of 15 to 22 inches. This range fits people 5'-6'4". The feet should be level on the floor, and the knees should be 90 degrees.


width

The standard seat width is 17 to 20 inches to support thighs. Each user should have adequate legroom and hip clearance on a high-quality seat pan, with no more than an extra inch on either side.


Seat-depth

If you want to sit on an ergonomically correct office chair, the seat must be deep enough so that your back rests against the backrest but shallow enough so that you can fit two to four fingers between the bottom of the chair and your knees.


Lumbar

Adjustable lumbar support is a must. The lumbar spine helps keep your upper body steady, including your head and neck. The chair's backrest serves several functions: it protects the spine, restricts leg motion, and enables truncal movement.


Backrest

Backrests are 12 to 19 inches wide. It must support the back curve. A good ergonomic chair will encourage movement rather than immobility as you work to improve circulation.
